subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Re: Lexical sets and QS letters
msgSnippet: ... I ve been thinking about this a bit all day, but just now have had a chance to post. How does QS handle these situations? Australian English (Aussie):
messageBody:
Anthony Grahn wrote:


>
> Now if we let Americans use #30 for the word "path" then we must
> let Tasmanians use #28 if they want. I have observed that this creates
> no difficulties in practice and we will still all be able to read
> their towering body of literature without difficulty.
>

I've been thinking about this a bit all day, but just now have had a
chance to post. How does QS handle these situations?

Australian English (Aussie): "buy" pronounced like "boy" to us, spelled
"Bob" "Oy?"

American English: "boy," spelled "Bob" "Oy."

So we wouldn't be able to distinguish between the words "buy" and "boy"
if we didn't know what kind of English was being used?

In contrast, John, are you saying that since "buy" belongs to the PRICE
lexical set, that any user always uses "Bob" "Ice" for the spelling?

I'm not advocating either way, but just trying to clarify if I
understand things correctly.

Paul
